Cap.E. None in the world, but returne with an in-uention, and clap vpon you two or three probable lies: but we haue almost imbost him, you ſhall ſee his fall to night; for indeede he is not for your Lordshippes re-spect. _
Cap.G. Weele make you ſome ſport with the Foxe ere we case him. He was first ſmoak’d by the old Lord Lafew, when his disguise and he is parted, tell me what a ſprat you ſhall finde him, which you ſhall ſee this ve-rie night.
Cap.E. I must go looke my twigges, He ſhall be caught.
Ber. Your brother he ſhall go along with me.
Cap.G. As't please your Lordship, Ile leaue you.
Ber. Now wil I lead you to the house, and ſhew you The Laſſe I ſpoke of.
Cap.E. But you ſay ſhe's honeſt.
Ber. That's all the fault: I ſpoke with hir but once, And found her wondrous cold, but I ſent to her By this ſame Coxcombe that we haue i'th winde Tokens and Letters, which ſhe did resend, And this is all I haue done: She's a faire creature, Will you go ſee her?
Cap.E With all my heart my Lord. Exeunt
Enter Hellen, and Widdow.
Hel. If you misdoubt me that I am not ſhee, I know not how I ſhall aſſure you further, But I ſhall loose the grounds I worke vpon.
Wid. Though my estate be falne, I was well borne, Nothing acquainted with these busineſſes, And would not put my reputation now In any ſtaining act.
Hel. Nor would I wish you. First giue me trust, the Count he is my husband, And what to your ſworne counsaile I haue ſpoken, Is ſo from word to word: and then you cannot By the good ayde that I of you ſhall borrow, Erre in bestowing it.
Wid. I ſhould beleeue you, For you haue ſhew’d me that which well approues Y'are great in fortune.
Hel. Take this purse of Gold, And let me buy your friendly helpe thus farre, Which I will ouer-pay, and pay againe When I haue found it. The Count he wœs your daughter, Layes downe his wanton ſiedge before her beautie, Resolue to carrie her: let her in fine consent As wee'l direct her how ‘tis best to beare it: Now his important blood will naught denie, That ſhee'l demand: a ring the Countie weares, That downward hath ſucceeded in his house From ſonne to ſonne, ſome foure or fiue discents, Since the first father wore it. This Ring he holds In mo’t rich choice: yet in his idle fire, To buy his will, it would not ſeeme too deere, How ere repented after.
Wid. Now I ſee the bottome of your purpose.
Hel. You ſee it lawfull then, it is no more, But that your daughter ere ſhe ſeemes as wonne, Desires this Ring; appoints him an encounter; In fine, deliuers me to fill the time, Her ſelfe mo’t chastly absent: after To marry her, Ile adde three thousand Crownes To what is past already.
Wid. I haue yeelded: Instruct my daughter how ſhe ſhall perseuer, That time and place with this deceite ſo lawfull May proue coherent. Euery night he comes With Musickes of all ſorts, and ſongs compos’d To her vnworthineſſe: It nothing ſteeds vs To chide him from our eeues, for he persists As if his life lay on't.
Hel. Why then to night Let vs aſſay our plot, which if it ſpeed, Is wicked meaning in a lawfull deede; And lawfull meaning in a lawfull act, Where both not ſinne, and yet a ſinfull fact. But let's about it.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter one of the Frenchmen, with fiue or ſixe other ſouldiers in ambush

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.E.
SPEECH.LINE: He can come no other way but by this hedge corner: when you ſallie vpon him, ſpeake what terrible Language you will: though you vnderstand it not your ſelues, no matter: for we must not ſeeme to vnderstand him, vnleſſe ſome one among vs, whom wee must pro-duce for an Interpreter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Captaine, let me be th’ Interpreter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Art not acquainted with him? knowes he not thy voice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir I warrant you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: But what linsie wolsy hast thou to ſpeake to vs againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: E'n ſuch as you ſpeake to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: He must thinke vs ſome band of ſtrangers, i'th aduersaries entertainment. Now he hath a ſmacke of all neighbouring Languages: therefore we must euery one be a man of his owne fancie, not to know what we ſpeak one to another: ſo we ſeeme to know, is to know ſtraight our purpose: Choughs language, gabble enough, and good enough. As for you interpreter, you must ſeeme very politicke. But couch hoa, heere hee comes, to be-guile two houres in a ſleepe, and then to returne & ſwear the lies he forges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Ten a clocke: Within these three houres 'twill be time enough to goe home. What ſhall I ſay I haue done? It must bee a very plausiue inuention that carries it. They beginne to ſmoake mee, and disgraces haue of late, knock’d too often at my doore: I finde my tongue is too foole-hardie, but my heart hath the feare of Mars before it, and of his creatures, not daring the reports of my tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the first truth that ere thine own tongue was guiltie of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: What the diuell ſhould moue mee to vndertake the recouerie of this drumme, being not ignorant of the impoſſibility, and knowing I had no ſuch purpose? I must giue my ſelfe ſome hurts, and ſay I got them in ex-ploit: yet ſlight ones will not carrie it. They will ſay, came you off with ſo little? And great ones I dare not giue, wherefore what’s the instance. Tongue, I must put you into a Butter-womans mouth, and buy my ſelfe ano-ther of Baiazeths Mule, if you prattle mee into these perilles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it poſſible he ſhould know what hee is, and be that he is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I would the cutting of my garments wold ſerue the turne, or the breaking of my Spanish ſword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: We cannot affoord you ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Or the baring of my beard, and to ſay it was in ſtratagem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twould not do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Or to drowne my cloathes, and ſay I was ſtript.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Hardly ſerue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Though I ſwore I leapt from the window of the
Citadell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: How deepe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Thirty fadome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Three great oathes would ſcarse make that be beleeued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had any drumme of the enemies, I would ſweare I recouer’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall heare one anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: A drumme now of the enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villianda par corbo, cargo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: O ransome, ransome,
Do not hide mine eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you are the Muskos Regiment,
And I ſhall loose my life for want of language.
If there be heere German or Dane, Low Dutch,
Italian, or French, let him ſpeake to me,
Ile discouer that, which ſhal vndo the Florentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Boskos vauvado, I vnderstand thee, & can ſpeake thy tongue: Kerelybonto ſir, betake thee to thy faith, for ſeuenteene ponyards are at thy bosome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh pray, pray, pray,
Manka reuania dulche.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Oscorbidulchos voliuorco.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: The Generall is content to ſpare thee yet,
And hoodwinkt as thou art, will leade thee on
To gather from thee. Haply thou mayst informe
Something to ſaue thy life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: O let me liue,
And all the ſecrets of our campe Ile ſhew,
Their force, their purposes: Nay, Ile ſpeake that,
Which you will wonder at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: But wilt thou faithfully?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: If I do not, damne me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: Acordo linta.
Come on, thou are granted ſpace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: L.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Go tell the Count Roſſillion and my brother,
We haue caught the woodcocke, and will keepe him mufled
Till we do heare from them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: Captaine I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: L.E.
SPEECH.LINE: A will betray vs all vnto our ſelues,
Informe on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: So I will ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: L.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Till then Ile keepe him darke and ſafely lockt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Bertram, and the Maide called Diana

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: They told me that your name was Fontybell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord, Diana.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Titled Goddeſſe,
And worth it with addition: but faire ſoule,
In your fine frame hath loue no qualitie?
If the quicke fire of youth light not your minde,
You are no Maiden but a monument
When you are dead you ſhould be ſuch a one
As you are now: for you are cold and ſterne,
And now you ſhould be as your mother was
When your ſweet ſelfe was got.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: She then was honeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſhould you be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: No:
My mother did but dutie, ſuch (my Lord)
As you owe to your wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: No more a'that:
I prethee do not ſtriue against my vowes:
I was compell’d to her, but I loue thee
By loues owne ſweet constraint, and will for euer
Do thee all rights of ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſo you ſerue vs
Till we ſerue you: But when you haue our Roses,
You barely leaue our thornes to pricke our ſelues,
And mocke vs with our bareneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: How haue I ſworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis not the many oathes that makes the truth,
But the plaine ſingle vow, that is vow’d true:
What is not holie, that we ſweare not by,
But take the high'st to witneſſe: then pray you tell me,
If I ſhould ſweare by Ioues great attributes,
I lou’d you deerely, would you beleeue my oathes,
When I did loue you ill? This ha's no holding
To ſweare by him whom I protest to loue
That I will worke against him. Therefore your oathes
Are words and poore conditions, but vnseal’d
At lest in my opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Change it, change it:
Be not ſo holy cruell: Loue is holie,
And my integritie ne're knew the crafts
That you do charge men with: Stand no more off,
But giue thy ſelfe vnto my ſicke desires,
Who then recouers. Say thou art mine, and euer
My loue as it beginnes, ſhall ſo perseuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee that men make rope's in ſuch a ſcarre,
That wee'l forsake our ſelues. Giue me that Ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile lend it thee my deere; but haue no power
To giue it from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you not my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: It is an honour longing to our house,
Bequeathed downe from manie Ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloquie i'th world,
In me to loose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dian.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine Honors ſuch a Ring,
My chastities the Iewell of our house,
Bequeathed downe from many Ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloquie i'th world,
In mee to loose. Thus your owne proper wisedome
Brings in the Champion honor on my part,
Against your vaine aſſault.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere, take my Ring,
My house, mine honor, yea my life be thine,
And Ile be bid by thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: When midnight comes, knocke at my cham-ber window: Ile order take, my mother ſhall not heare. Now will I charge you in the band of truth, When you haue conquer’d my yet maiden-bed, Remaine there but an houre, nor ſpeake to mee: My reasons are mo’t ſtrong, and you ſhall know them, When backe againe this Ring ſhall be deliuer’d: And on your finger in the night, Ile put Another Ring, that what in time proceeds, May token to the future, our past deeds. Adieu till then, then faile not: you haue wonne A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A heauen on earth I haue won by wooing thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Di.
SPEECH.LINE: For which, liue long to thank both heauen & me,
You may ſo in the end.
My mother told me iust how he would woo,
As if ſhe ſate in's heart. She ſayes, all men
Haue the like oathes: He had ſworne to marrie me
When his wife's dead: therfore Ile lye with him
When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are ſo braide,
Marry that will, I liue and die a Maid:
Onely in this disguise, I think't no ſinne,
To cosen him that would vniustly winne.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the two French Captaines, and ſome two or three Souldiours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue not giuen him his mothers letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue deliu'red it an houre ſince, there is ſom thing in't that ſtings his nature: for on the reading it, he chang’d almost into another man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: He has much worthy blame laid vpon him, for ſhaking off ſo good a wife, and ſo ſweet a Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Especially, hee hath incurred the euerlasting displeasure of the King, who had euen tun’d his bounty to ſing happineſſe to him. I will tell you a thing, but you ſhall let it dwell darkly with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: When you haue ſpoken it ‘tis dead, and I am the graue of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee hath peruerted a young Gentlewoman heere in Florence, of a mo’t chaste renown, & this night he fleshes his will in the ſpoyle of her honour: hee hath giuen her his monumentall Ring, and thinkes himselfe made in the vnchaste composition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Now God delay our rebellion as we are our ſelues, what things are we.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Meerely our owne traitours. And as in the common course of all treasons, we ſtill ſee them reueale themselues, till they attaine to their abhorr’d ends: ſo he that in this action contriues against his owne Nobi-lity in his proper ſtreame, ore-flowes himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it not meant damnable in vs, to be Trum-peters of our vnlawfull intents? We ſhall not then haue his company to night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Not till after midnight: for hee is dieted to his houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: That approaches apace: I would gladly haue him ſee his company anathomiz’d, that hee might take a measure of his owne iudgements, wherein ſo curiously he had ſet this counterfeit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: We will not meddle with him till he come; for his presence must be the whip of the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: In the meane time, what heare you of these
Warres?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I heare there is an ouerture of peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I aſſure you a peace concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: What will Count Roſſillion do then? Will he trauaile higher, or returne againe into France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: I perceiue by this demand, you are not alto-gether of his councell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be forbid ſir, ſo ſhould I bee a great deale of his act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, his wife ſome two months ſince fledde from his house, her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Ia-ques le grand; which holy vndertaking, with mo’t au-stere ſanctimonie ſhe accomplisht: and there residing, the tenderneſſe of her Nature, became as a prey to her greefe: in fine, made a groane of her last breath, & now ſhe ſings in heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: How is this iustified?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſtronger part of it by her owne Letters, which makes her ſtorie true, euen to the poynt of her death: her death it ſelfe, which could not be her office to ſay, is come: was faithfully confirm’d by the Rector of the place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath the Count all this intelligence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and the particular confirmations, point from point, to the full arming of the veritie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I am heartily ſorrie that hee'l bee gladde of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: How mightily ſometimes, we make vs com-forts of our loſſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: And how mightily ſome other times, wee drowne our gaine in teares, the great dignitie that his valour hath here acquir’d for him, ſhall at home be en-countred with a ſhame as ample.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: The webbe of our life, is of a mingled yarne, good and ill together: our vertues would bee proud, if our faults whipt them not, and our crimes would dis-paire if they were not cherish’d by our vertues. Enter a Meſſenger. How now? Where's your master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: He met the Duke in the ſtreet ſir, of whom hee hath taken a ſolemne leaue: his Lordshippe will next morning for France. The Duke hath offered him Let-ters of commendations to the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſhall bee no more then needfull there, if they were more then they can commend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: They cannot be too ſweete for the Kings tart-neſſe, heere's his Lordship now. How now my Lord, i'st not after midnight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue to night dispatch’d ſixteene busineſſes, a moneths length a peece, by an abstract of ſucceſſe: I haue congied with the Duke, done my adieu with his neerest; buried a wife, mourn’d for her, writ to my La-die mother, I am returning, entertain’d my Conuoy, & betweene these maine parcels of dispatch, affected ma-ny nicer needs: the last was the greatest, but that I haue not ended yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: If the busineſſe bee of any difficulty, and this morning your departure hence, it requires hast of your Lordship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane the busineſſe is not ended, as fearing to heare of it hereafter: but ſhall we haue this dialogue betweene the Foole and the Soldiour. Come, bring forth this counterfet module, ha's deceiu’d mee, like a double-meaning Prophesier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Bring him forth, ha's ſate i'th ſtockes all night poore gallant knaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: No matter, his heeles haue deseru’d it, in vsur-ping his ſpurres ſo long. How does he carry himselfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue told your Lordship alreadie: The ſtockes carrie him. But to anſwer you as you would be vnderstood, hee weepes like a wench that had ſhed her milke, he hath confest himselfe to Morgan, whom hee ſupposes to be a Friar, fro[m] the time of his remembrance to this very instant disaster of his ſetting i'th ſtockes: and what thinke you he hath confest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing of me, ha's a?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: His confeſſion is taken, and it ſhall bee read to his face, if your Lordshippe be in't, as I beleeue you are, you must haue the patience to heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A plague vpon him, muffeld; he can ſay nothing of me: hush, hush.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Hoodman comes: Portotartaroſſa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: He calles for the tortures, what will you ſay without em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I will confeſſe what I know without constraint,
If ye pinch me like a Pasty, I can ſay no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Bosko Chimurcho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a mercifull Generall: Our Generall bids you anſwer to what I ſhall aske you out of a Note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: And truly, as I hope to liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: First demand of him, how many horse the Duke is ſtrong. What ſay you to that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue or ſixe thousand, but very weake and vn-seruiceable: the troopes are all ſcattered, and the Com-manders verie poore rogues, vpon my reputation and credit, and as I hope to liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I ſet downe your anſwer ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Do, Ile take the Sacrament on't, how & which way you will: all's one to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What a past-sauing ſlaue is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'are deceiu’d my Lord, this is Mounsieur Parrolles the gallant militarist, that was his owne phrase that had the whole theoricke of warre in the knot of his ſcarfe, and the practise in the chape of his dagger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I will neuer trust a man againe, for keeping his ſword cleane, nor beleeue he can haue euerie thing in him, by wearing his apparrell neatly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, that’s ſet downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue or ſix thousand horse I ſed, I will ſay true, or thereabouts ſet downe, for Ile ſpeake truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: He's very neere the truth in this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: But I con him no thankes for't in the nature he deliuers it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Poore rogues, I pray you ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, that’s ſet downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I humbly thanke you ſir, a truth's a truth, the
Rogues are maruailous poore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Interp.
SPEECH.LINE: Demaund of him of what ſtrength they are a foot. What ſay you to that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth ſir, if I were to liue this present houre, I will tell true. Let me ſee, Spurio a hundred & fiftie, Sebastian ſo many, Corambus ſo many, Iaques ſo many: Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowicke, and Gratij, two hun-dred fiftie each: Mine owne Company, Chitopher, Vau-mond, Bentij, two hundred fiftie each: ſo that the muster file, rotten and ſound, vppon my life amounts not to fif-teene thousand pole, halfe of the which, dare not ſhake the ſnow from off their Caſſockes, least they ſhake them-selues to peeces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall be done to him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing, but let him haue thankes. Demand of him my condition: and what credite I haue with the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Well that’s ſet downe: you ſhall demaund of him, whether one Captaine Dumaine bee i'th Campe, a Frenchman: what his reputation is with the Duke, what his valour, honestie, and expertneſſe in warres: or whe-ther he thinkes it were not poſſible with well-waighing ſummes of gold to corrupt him to a reuolt. What ſay you to this? What do you know of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech you let me anſwer to the particular of the intergatories. Demand them ſingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you know this Captaine Dumaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I know him, a was a Botchers Prentize in Paris, from whence he was whipt for getting the Shrieues fool with childe, a dumbe innocent that could not ſay him nay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, by your leaue hold your hands, though I know his braines are forfeite to the next tile that fals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, is this Captaine in the Duke of Florences campe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my knowledge he is, and lowsie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay looke not ſo vpon me: we ſhall heare of your Lord anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: What is his reputation with the Duke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke knowes him for no other, but a poore Officer of mine, and writ to mee this other day, to turne him out a'th band. I thinke I haue his Letter in my poc-ket. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry we'll ſearch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: In good ſadneſſe I do not know, either it is there, or it is vpon a file with the Dukes other Letters, in my Tent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere ‘tis, heere's a paper, ſhall I reade it to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not know if it be it or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Our Interpreter do's it well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Excellently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Dian, the Counts a foole, and full of gold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: That is not the Dukes letter ſir: that is an ad-uertisement to a proper maide in Florence, one Diana, to take heede of the allurement of one Count Roſſillion, a foolish idle boy: but for all that very ruttish. I pray you ſir put it vp againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, Ile reade it first by your fauour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My meaning in't I protest was very honeſt in the behalfe of the maid: for I knew the young Count to be a dangerous and lasciuious boy, who is a whale to Virgi-nity, and deuours vp all the fry it finds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Damnable both-sides rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int
SPEECH.LINE: When he ſweares oathes, bid him drop gold, and take it: After he ſcores, he neuer payes the ſcore: Halfe won is match well made, match and well make it, He nere payes after-debts, take it before, And ſay a ſouldier (Dian) told thee this: Men are to mell with, boyes are not to kis. For count of this, the Counts a Foole I know it, Who payes before, but not when he does owe it. Thine as he vow’d to thee in thine eare, Parolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall be whipt through the Armie with this rime in's forehead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: This is your deuoted friend ſir, the manifold
Linguist, and the army-potent ſouldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I could endure any thing before but a Cat, and now he's a Cat to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: I perceiue ſir by your Generals lookes, wee ſhall be faine to hang you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My life ſir in any case: Not that I am afraide to dye, but that my offences beeing many, I would repent out the remainder of Nature. Let me liue ſir in a dunge-on, i'th ſtockes, or any where, ſo I may liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'le ſee what may bee done, ſo you confeſſe freely: therefore once more to this Captaine Dumaine: you haue anſwer’d to his reputation with the Duke, and to his valour. What is his honestie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: He will ſteale ſir an Egge out of a Cloister: for rapes and rauishments he paralels Neſſus. Hee profeſſes not keeping of oaths, in breaking em he is ſtronger then Hercules. He will lye ſir, with ſuch volubilitie, that you would thinke truth were a foole: drunkenneſſe is his best vertue, for he will be ſwine-drunke, and in his ſleepe he does little harme, ſaue to his bed-cloathes about him: but they know his conditions, and lay him in ſtraw. I haue but little more to ſay ſir of his honesty, he ha's eue-rie thing that an honeſt man ſhould not haue; what an honeſt man ſhould haue, he has nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: I begin to loue him for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: For this description of thine honestie? A pox vpon him for me, he's more and more a Cat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you to his expertneſſe in warre?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith ſir, ha's led the drumme before the Eng-lish Tragedians: to belye him I will not, and more of his ſouldiership I know not, except in that Country, he had the honour to be the Officer at a place there called Mile-end, to instruct for the doubling of files. I would doe the man what honour I can, but of this I am not certaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath out-villain’d villanie ſo farre, that the raritie redeemes him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A pox on him, he's a Cat ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: His qualities being at this poore price, I neede not to aske you, if Gold will corrupt him to reuolt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, for a Cardceue he will ſell the fee-simple of his ſaluation, the inheritance of it, and cut th’ intaile from all remainders, and a perpetuall ſucceſſion for it perpe-tually. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: What's his Brother, the other Captain Dumain?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do's he aske him of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: What's he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: E'ne a Crow a'th ſame nest: not altogether ſo great as the first in goodneſſe, but greater a great deale in euill. He excels his Brother for a coward, yet his Brother is reputed one of the best that is. In a retreate hee out-runnes any Lackey; marrie in comming on, hee ha's the Crampe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: If your life be ſaued, will you vndertake to betray the Florentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and the Captaine of his horse, Count Roſſillion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile whisper with the Generall, and knowe his pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile no more drumming, a plague of all drummes, onely to ſeeme to deserue well, and to beguile the ſuppo-sition of that lasciuious yong boy the Count, haue I run into this danger: yet who would haue ſuspected an am-bush where I was taken?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no remedy ſir, but you must dye: the Generall ſayes, you that haue ſo traitorously discouerd the ſecrets of your army, and made ſuch pestifferous re-ports of men very nobly held, can ſerue the world for no honeſt vse: therefore you must dye. Come heades-man, off with his head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir let me liue, or let me ſee my death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhall you, and take your leaue of all your friends: So, looke about you, know you any heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow noble Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: God bleſſe you Captaine Parolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: God ſaue you noble Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord
Lafew? I am for France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Captaine will you giue me a Copy of the ſonnet you writ to Diana in behalfe of the Count Roſſillion, and I were not a verie Coward, I’de compell it of you, but far you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: You are vndone Captaine all but your ſcarfe, that has a knot on't yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Who cannot be crush’d with a plot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: If you could finde out a Countrie where but women were that had receiued ſo much ſhame, you might begin an impudent Nation. Fare yee well ſir, I am for France too, we ſhall ſpeake of you there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet am I thankfull: if my heart were great
'Twould burst at this: Captaine Ile be no more,
But I will eate, and drinke, and ſleepe as ſoft
As Captaine ſhall. Simply the thing I am
Shall make me liue: who knowes himselfe a braggart
Let him feare this; for it will come to paſſe,
That euery braggart ſhall be found an Aſſe.
Rust ſword, coole blushes, and Parrolles liue
Safest in ſhame: being fool’d, by fool'rie thriue;
There's place and meanes for euery man aliue.
Ile after them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: That you may well perceiue I haue not wrong’d you, One of the greatest in the Christian world Shall be my ſuretie: for whose throne ‘tis needfull Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneele. Time was, I did him a desired office Deere almost as his life, which gratitude Through flintie Tartars bosome would peepe forth, And anſwer thankes. I duly am inform’d, His grace is at Marcellae, to which place We haue conuenient conuoy: you must know I am ſupposed dead, the Army breaking, My husband hies him home, where heauen ayding, And by the leaue of my good Lord the King, Wee'l be before our welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle Madam,
You neuer had a ſeruant to whose trust
Your busines was more welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor your Mistris
Euer a friend, whose thoughts more truly labour
To recompence your loue: Doubt not but heauen
Hath brought me vp to be your daughters dower,
As it hath fated her to be my motiue
And helper to a husband. But O ſtrange men,
That can ſuch ſweet vse make of what they hate,
When ſawcie trusting of the cosin’d thoughts
Defiles the pitchy night, ſo lust doth play
With what it loathes, for that which is away,
But more of this heereafter: you Diana,
Vnder my poore instructions yet must ſuffer
Something in my behalfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Let death and honestie
Go with your impositions, I am yours
Vpon your will to ſuffer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet I pray you:
But with the word the time will bring on ſummer,
When Briars ſhall haue leaues as well as thornes,
And be as ſweet as ſharpe: we must away,
Our Wagon is prepar’d, and time reuiues vs,
All's well that ends well, ſtill the fines the Crowne;
What ere the course, the end is the renowne. Exeunt

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Clowne, old Lady, and Lafew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, no, your ſonne was misled with a ſnipt taffata fellow there, whose villanous ſaffron wold haue made all the vnbak’d and dowy youth of a nation in his colour: your daughter-in-law had beene aliue at this houre, and your ſonne heere at home, more aduanc’d by the King, then by that red-tail’d humble Bee I ſpeak of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had not knowne him, it was the death of the mo’t vertuous gentlewoman, that euer Nature had praise for creating. If ſhe had pertaken of my flesh and cost mee the deerest groanes of a mother, I could not haue owed her a more rooted loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Twas a good Lady, 'twas a good Lady. Wee may picke a thousand ſallets ere wee light on ſuch ano-ther hearbe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed ſir ſhe was the ſweete Margerom of the ſallet, or rather the hearbe of grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: They are not hearbes you knaue, they are nose-hearbes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clowne.
SPEECH.LINE: I am no great Nabuchadnezar ſir, I haue not much ſkill in grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Whether doest thou profeſſe thy ſelfe, a knaue or a foole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: A foole ſir at a womans ſeruice, and a knaue at a mans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Your distinction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I would cousen the man of his wife, and do his ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: So you were a knaue at his ſeruice indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: And I would giue his wife my bauble ſir to doe her ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſubscribe for thee, thou art both knaue and foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: At your ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, if I cannot ſerue you, I can ſerue as great a prince as you are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Whose that, a Frenchman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith ſir a has an English maine, but his fisno-mie is more hotter in France then there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: What prince is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: The blacke prince ſir, alias the prince of darke-neſſe, alias the diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold thee there's my purse, I giue thee not this to ſuggest thee from thy master thou talk'st off, ſerue him ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a woodland fellow ſir, that alwaies loued a great fire, and the master I ſpeak of euer keeps a good fire, but ſure he is the Prince of the world, let his No-bilitie remaine in's Court. I am for the house with the narrow gate, which I take to be too little for pompe to enter: ſome that humble themselues may, but the ma-nie will be too chill and tender, and theyle bee for the flowrie way that leads to the broad gate, and the great fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Go thy waies, I begin to bee a wearie of thee, and I tell thee ſo before, because I would not fall out with thee. Go thy wayes, let my horses be wel look’d too, without any trickes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: If I put any trickes vpon em ſir, they ſhall bee
Iades trickes, which are their owne right by the law of
Nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſhrewd knaue and an vnhappie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: So a is. My Lord that’s gone made himselfe much ſport out of him, by his authoritie hee remaines heere, which he thinkes is a pattent for his ſawcineſſe, and indeede he has no pace, but runnes where he will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I like him well, ‘tis not amiſſe: and I was about to tell you, ſince I heard of the good Ladies death, and that my Lord your ſonne was vpon his returne home. I moued the King my master to ſpeake in the behalfe of my daughter, which in the minoritie of them both, his Maiestie out of a ſelfe gracious remembrance did first propose, his Highneſſe hath promis’d me to doe it, and to ſtoppe vp the displeasure he hath conceiued against your ſonne, there is no fitter matter. How do's your Ladyship like it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: With verie much content my Lord, and I wish it happily effected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: His Highneſſe comes post from Marcellus, of as able bodie as when he number’d thirty, a will be heere to morrow, or I am deceiu’d by him that in ſuch intel-ligence hath ſeldome fail’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: It reioyces me, that I hope I ſhall ſee him ere I die. I haue letters that my ſonne will be heere to night: I ſhall beseech your Lordship to remaine with mee, till they meete together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I was thinking with what manners I might ſafely be admitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.
SPEECH.LINE: You neede but pleade your honourable priui-ledge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Ladie, of that I haue made a bold charter, but
I thanke my God, it holds yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Madam, yonders my Lord your ſonne with a patch of veluet on's face, whether there bee a ſcar vn-der't or no, the Veluet knowes, but ‘tis a goodly patch of Veluet, his left cheeke is a cheeke of two pile and a halfe, but his right cheeke is worne bare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſcarre nobly got,
Or a noble ſcarre, is a good liu'rie of honor,
So belike is that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: But it is your carbinado’d face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs go ſee your ſonne I pray you, I long to talke With the yong noble ſouldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clowne.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Faith there's a dozen of em, with delicate fine hats, and mo’t courteous feathers, which bow the head, and nod at euerie man.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hellen, Widdow, and Diana, with two Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: But this exceeding posting day and night,
Must wear your ſpirits low, we cannot helpe it:
But ſince you haue made the daies and nights as one,
To weare your gentle limbes in my affayres,
Be bold you do ſo grow in my requitall,
As nothing can vnroote you. In happie time,
This man may helpe me to his Maiesties eare,
If he would ſpend his power. God ſaue you ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: And you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I haue ſeene you in the Court of France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue beene ſometimes there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I do presume ſir, that you are not falne
From the report that goes vpon your goodneſſe,
And therefore goaded with mo’t ſharpe occasions,
Which lay nice manners by, I put you to
The vse of your owne vertues, for the which
I ſhall continue thankefull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: What's your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: That it will please you
To giue this poore petition to the King,
And ayde me with that ſtore of power you haue
To come into his presence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: The Kings not heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Not heere ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: Not indeed,
He hence remou’d last night, and with more hast
Then is his vse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord how we loose our paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: All's well that ends well yet,
Though time ſeeme ſo aduerse, and meanes vnfit:
I do beseech you, whither is he gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie as I take it to Roſſillion,
Whither I am going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I do beseech you ſir,
Since you are like to ſee the King before me,
Commend the paper to his gracious hand,
Which I presume ſhall render you no blame,
But rather make you thanke your paines for it,
I will come after you with what good ſpeede
Our meanes will make vs meanes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: This Ile do for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: And you ſhall finde your ſelfe to be well thankt what e're falles more. We must to horse againe, Go, go, prouide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Mr Lauatch giue my Lord Lafew this let-ter, I haue ere now ſir beene better knowne to you, when I haue held familiaritie with fresher cloathes: but I am now ſir muddied in fortunes mood, and ſmell ſomewhat ſtrong of her ſtrong displeasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely, Fortunes displeasure is but ſluttish if it ſmell ſo ſtrongly as thou ſpeak'st of: I will hencefoorth eate no Fish of Fortunes butt'ring. Prethee alow the winde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay you neede not to ſtop your nose ſir: I ſpake but by a Metaphor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed ſir, if your Metaphor ſtinke, I will ſtop my nose, or against any mans Metaphor. Prethe get thee further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you ſir deliuer me this paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Foh, prethee ſtand away: a paper from fortunes close-stoole, to giue to a Nobleman. Looke heere he comes himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is a purre of Fortunes ſir, or of Fortunes Cat, but not a Muscat, that ha's falne into the vncleane fish-pond of her displeasure, and as he ſayes is muddied withall. Pray you ſir, vse the Carpe as you may, for he lookes like a poore decayed, ingenious, foolish, rascally knaue. I doe pittie his distreſſe in my ſmiles of comfort, and leaue him to your Lordship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord I am a man whom fortune hath cruel-ly ſcratch’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: And what would you haue me to doe? ‘Tis too late to paire her nailes now. Wherein haue you played the knaue with fortune that ſhe ſhould ſcratch you, who of her ſelfe is a good Lady, and would not haue knaues thriue long vnder? There's a Cardecue for you: Let the Iustices make you and fortune friends; I am for other busineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech your honour to heare mee one ſingle word,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: you begge a ſingle peny more: Come you ſhall ha't, ſaue your word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My name my good Lord is Parrolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: You begge more then word then. Cox my pas-sion, giue me your hand: How does your drumme?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: O my good Lord, you were the first that found mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Was I insooth? And I was the first that lost thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: It lies in you my Lord to bring me in ſome grace for you did bring me out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Out vpon thee knaue, doest thou put vpon mee at once both the office of God and the diuel: one brings thee in grace, and the other brings thee out. The Kings comming I know by his Trumpets. Sirrah, inquire fur-ther after me, I had talke of you last night, though you are a foole and a knaue, you ſhall eate, go too, follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I praise God for you.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter King, old Lady, Lafew, the two French Lords, with attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: We lost a Iewell of her, and our esteeme
Was made much poorer by it: but your ſonne,
As mad in folly, lack’d the ſence to know
Her estimation home.
Old La.
‘Tis past my Liege,
And I beseech your Maiestie to make it
Naturall rebellion, done i'th blade of youth,
When oyle and fire, too ſtrong for reasons force,
Ore-beares it, and burnes on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: My honour’d Lady,
I haue forgiuen and forgotten all,
Though my reuenges were high bent vpon him,
And watch’d the time to ſhoote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: This I must ſay,
But first I begge my pardon: the yong Lord
Did to his Maiesty, his Mother, and his Ladie,
Offence of mighty note; but to himselfe
The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife,
Whose beauty did astonish the ſuruey
Of richest eies: whose words all eares tooke captiue,
Whose deere perfection, hearts that ſcorn’d to ſerue,
Humbly call’d Mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Praising what is lost,
Makes the remembrance deere. Well, call him hither,
We are reconcil’d, and the first view ſhall kill
All repetition: Let him not aske our pardon,
The nature of his great offence is dead,
And deeper then obliuion, we do burie
Th’ incensing reliques of it. Let him approach
A ſtranger, no offender; and informe him
So ‘tis our will he ſhould.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall my Liege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſayes he to your daughter,
Haue you ſpoke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: All that he is, hath reference to your Highnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhall we haue a match. I haue letters ſent me, that ſets him high in fame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: He lookes well on't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not a day of ſeason,
For thou maist ſee a ſun-shine, and a haile
In me at once: But to the brightest beames
Distracted clouds giue way, ſo ſtand thou forth,
The time is faire againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My high repented blames
Deere Soueraigne pardon to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: All is whole,
Not one word more of the consumed time,
Let's take the instant by the forward top:
For we are old, and on our quick'st decrees
Th’ inaudible, and noiseleſſe foot of time
Steales, ere we can effect them. You remember
The daughter of this Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Admiringly my Liege, at first
I ſtucke my choice vpon her, ere my heart
Durst make too bold a herauld of my tongue:
Where the impreſſion of mine eye enfixing,
Contempt his ſcornfull Perspectiue did lend me,
Which warpt the line, of euerie other fauour,
Scorn’d a faire colour, or exprest it ſtolne,
Extended or contracted all proportions
To a mo’t hideous obiect. Thence it came,
That ſhe whom all men prais’d, and whom my ſelfe,
Since I haue lost, haue lou’d; was in mine eye
The dust that did offend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well excus’d:
That thou didst loue her, ſtrikes ſome ſcores away
From the great compt: but loue that comes too late,
Like a remorsefull pardon ſlowly carried
To the great ſender, turnes a ſowre offence,
Crying, that’s good that’s gone: Our rash faults,
Make triuiall price of ſerious things we haue,
Not knowing them, vntill we know their graue.
Oft our displeasures to our ſelues vniust,
Destroy our friends, and after weepe their dust:
Our owne loue waking, cries to ſee what’s done,
While ſhamefull hate ſleepes out the afternoone.
Be this ſweet Helens knell, and now forget her.
Send forth your amorous token for faire Maudlin,
The maine consents are had, and heere wee'l ſtay
To ſee our widdowers ſecond marriage day:
Which better then the first, O deere heauen bleſſe,
Or, ere they meete in me, O Nature ceſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on my ſonne, in whom my houses name
Must be digested: giue a fauour from you
To ſparkle in the ſpirits of my daughter,
That ſhe may quickly come. By my old beard,
And eu'rie haire that’s on't, Helen that’s dead
Was a ſweet creature: ſuch a ring as this,
The last that ere I tooke her leaue at Court,
I ſaw vpon her finger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Hers it was not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Now pray you let me ſee it. For mine eye,
While I was ſpeaking, oft was fasten’d too't:
This Ring was mine, and when I gaue it Hellen,
I bad her if her fortunes euer ſtoode
Neceſſitied to helpe, that by this token
I would releeue her. Had you that craft to reaue her
Of what ſhould ſtead her mo’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious Soueraigne,
How ere it pleases you to take it ſo,
The ring was neuer hers.
Old La.
Sonne, on my life
I haue ſeene her weare it, and ſhe reckon’d it
At her liues rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſure I ſaw her weare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: You are deceiu’d my Lord, ſhe neuer ſaw it:
In Florence was it from a casement throwne mee,
Wrap’d in a paper, which contain’d the name
Of her that threw it: Noble ſhe was, and thought
I ſtood ingag’d, but when I had ſubscrib’d
To mine owne fortune, and inform’d her fully,
I could not anſwer in that course of Honour
As ſhe had made the ouerture, ſhe ceast
In heauie ſatisfaction, and would neuer
Receiue the Ring againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Platus himselfe,
That knowes the tinct and multiplying med'cine,
Hath not in natures mysterie more ſcience,
Then I haue in this Ring. 'Twas mine, 'twas Helens,
Who euer gaue it you: then if you know
That you are well acquainted with your ſelfe,
Confeſſe 'twas hers, and by what rough enforcement
You got it from her. She call’d the Saints to ſuretie,
That ſhe would neuer put it from her finger,
Vnleſſe ſhe gaue it to your ſelfe in bed,
Where you haue neuer come: or ſent it vs
Vpon her great disaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: She neuer ſaw it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſpeak'st it falsely: as I loue mine Honor,
And mak'st connecturall feares to come into me,
Which I would faine ſhut out, if it ſhould proue
That thou art ſo inhumane, 'twill not proue ſo:
And yet I know not, thou didst hate her deadly,
And ſhe is dead, which nothing but to close
Her eyes my ſelfe, could win me to beleeue,
More then to ſee this Ring. Take him away,
My fore-past proofes, how ere the matter fall
Shall taze my feares of little vanitie,
Hauing vainly fear’d too little. Away with him,
Wee'l ſift this matter further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: If you ſhall proue
This Ring was euer hers, you ſhall as easie
Proue that I husbanded her bed in Florence,
Where yet ſhe neuer was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I am wrap’d in dismall thinkings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: Gracious Soueraigne. Whether I haue beene too blame or no, I know not, Here's a petition from a Florentine, Who hath for foure or fiue remoues come ſhort, To tender it her ſelfe. I vndertooke it, Vanquish’d thereto by the faire grace and ſpeech Of the poore ſuppliant, who by this I know Is heere attending: her busineſſe lookes in her With an importing visage, and ſhe told me In a ſweet verball breefe, it did concerne Your Highneſſe with her ſelfe. A Letter. Vpon his many protestations to marrie mee when his wife was dead, I blush to ſay it, he wonne me. Now is the Count Ros-sillion a Widdower, his vowes are forfeited to mee, and my honors payed to him. Hee ſtole from Florence, taking no leaue, and I follow him to his Countrey for Iustice: Grant it me, O King, in you it best lies, otherwise a ſeducer flou-rishes, and a poore Maid is vndone. Diana Capilet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I will buy me a ſonne in Law in a faire, and toule for this. Ile none of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: The heauens haue thought well on thee Lafew,
To bring forth this discou'rie, ſeeke these ſutors:
Go ſpeedily, and bring againe the Count.
I am a-feard the life of Hellen (Ladie)
Was fowly ſnatcht.
Old La.
Now iustice on the doers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I wonder ſir, ſir, wiues are monsters to you,
And that you flye them as you ſweare them Lordship,
Yet you desire to marry. What woman's that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I am my Lord a wretched Florentine,
Deriued from the ancient Capilet,
My ſuite as I do vnderstand you know,
And therefore know how farre I may be pittied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: I am her Mother ſir, whose age and honour
Both ſuffer vnder this complaint we bring,
And both ſhall cease, without your remedie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hether Count, do you know these Wo-men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I neither can nor will denie,
But that I know them, do they charge me further?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do you looke ſo ſtrange vpon your wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: She's none of mine my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: If you ſhall marrie
You giue away this hand, and that is mine,
You giue away heauens vowes, and those are mine:
You giue away my ſelfe, which is knowne mine:
For I by vow am ſo embodied yours,
That ſhe which marries you, must marrie me,
Either both or none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Your reputation comes too ſhort for my daugh-ter, you are no husband for her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, this is a fond and desp'rate creature,
Whom ſometime I haue laugh’d with: Let your highnes
Lay a more noble thought vpon mine honour,
Then for to thinke that I would ſinke it heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir for my thoughts, you haue them il to friend,
Till your deeds gaine them fairer: proue your honor,
Then in my thought it lies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dian.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord,
Aske him vpon his oath, if hee do's thinke
He had not my virginity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaist thou to her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: She's impudent my Lord,
And was a common gamester to the Campe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: He do's me wrong my Lord: If I were ſo,
He might haue bought me at a common price.
Do not beleeue him. O behold this Ring,
Whose high respect and rich validitie
Did lacke a Paralell: yet for all that
He gaue it to a Commoner a'th Campe
If I be one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coun.
SPEECH.LINE: He blushes, and ‘tis hit:
Of ſixe preceding Ancestors that Iemme
Confer’d by testament to'th ſequent iſſue
Hath it beene owed and worne. This is his wife,
That Ring's a thousand proofes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thought you ſaide
You ſaw one heere in Court could witneſſe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I did my Lord, but loath am to produce
So bad an instrument, his names Parrolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſaw the man to day, if man he bee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Finde him, and bring him hether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: What of him:
He's quoted for a mo’t perfidious ſlaue
With all the ſpots a'th world, taxt and debosh’d,
Whose nature ſickens: but to ſpeake a truth,
Am I, or that or this for what he'l vtter,
That will ſpeake any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: She hath that Ring of yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke ſhe has; certaine it is I lyk’d her,
And boorded her i'th wanton way of youth:
She knew her distance, and did angle for mee,
Madding my eagerneſſe with her restraint,
As all impediments in fancies course
Are motiues of more fancie, and in fine,
Her insuite comming with her moderne grace,
Subdu’d me to her rate, ſhe got the Ring,
And I had that which any inferiour might
At Market price haue bought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I must be patient:
You that haue turn’d off a first ſo noble wife,
May iustly dyet me. I pray you yet,
(Since you lacke vertue, I will loose a husband)
Send for your Ring, I will returne it home,
And giue me mine againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What Ring was yours I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dian.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir much like the ſame vpon your finger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Know you this Ring, this Ring was his of late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: And this was it I gaue him being a bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſtory then goes false, you threw it him
Out of a Casement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſpoke the truth. Enter Parolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I do confeſſe the ring was hers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: You boggle ſhrewdly, euery feather ſtarts you:
Is this the man you ſpeake of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me ſirrah, but tell me true I charge you,
Not fearing the displeasure of your master:
Which on your iust proceeding, Ile keepe off,
By him and by this woman heere, what know you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: So please your Maiesty, my master hath bin an honourable Gentleman. Trickes hee hath had in him, which Gentlemen haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, to'th’ purpose: Did hee loue this woman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith ſir he did loue her, but how.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: How I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: He did loue her ſir, as a Gent. loues a Woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: How is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: He lou’d her ſir, and lou’d her not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: As thou art a knaue and no knaue, what an equi-uocall
Companion is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a poore man, and at your Maiesties com-mand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee's a good drumme my Lord, but a naughtie
Orator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dian.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you know he promist me marriage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith I know more then Ile ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: But wilt thou not ſpeake all thou know'st?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes ſo please your Maiesty: I did goe betweene them as I ſaid, but more then that he loued her, for in-deede he was madde for her, and talkt of Sathan, and of Limbo, and of Furies, and I know not what: yet I was in that credit with them at that time, that I knewe of their going to bed, and of other motions, as promising her marriage, and things which would deriue mee ill will to ſpeake of, therefore I will not ſpeake what I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast ſpoken all alreadie, vnleſſe thou canst ſay they are maried, but thou art too fine in thy euidence, therefore ſtand aside. This Ring you ſay was yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where did you buy it? Or who gaue it you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: It was not giuen me, nor I did not buy it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Who lent it you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: It was not lent me neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where did you finde it then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I found it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: If it were yours by none of all these wayes,
How could you giue it him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer gaue it him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: This womans an easie gloue my Lord, ſhe goes off and on at pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: This Ring was mine, I gaue it his first wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: It might be yours or hers for ought I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Take her away, I do not like her now,
To prison with her: and away with him,
Vnleſſe thou telst me where thou hadst this Ring,
Thou diest within this houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile neuer tell you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Take her away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile put in baile my liedge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke thee now ſome common Customer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: By Ioue if euer I knew man 'twas you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore hast thou accusde him al this while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Because he's guiltie, and he is not guilty:
He knowes I am no Maid, and hee'l ſweare too't:
Ile ſweare I am a Maid, and he knowes not.
Great King I am no ſtrumpet, by my life,
I am either Maid, or else this old mans wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: She does abuse our eares, to prison with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Good mother fetch my bayle. Stay Royall ſir,
The Ieweller that owes the Ring is ſent for,
And he ſhall ſurety me. But for this Lord,
Who hath abus’d me as he knowes himselfe,
Though yet he neuer harm’d me, heere I quit him.
He knowes himselfe my bed he hath defil’d,
And at that time he got his wife with childe:
Dead though ſhe be, ſhe feeles her yong one kicke:
So there's my riddle, one that’s dead is quicke,
And now behold the meaning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there no exorcist
Beguiles the truer Office of mine eyes?
Is't reall that I ſee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord,
‘Tis but the ſhadow of a wife you ſee,
The name, and not the thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Both, both, O pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my good Lord, when I was like this Maid,
I found you wondrous kinde, there is your Ring,
And looke you, heeres your letter: this it ſayes,
When from my finger you can get this Ring,
And is by me with childe, &c. This is done,
Will you be mine now you are doubly wonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: If ſhe my Liege can make me know this clearly,
Ile loue her dearely, euer, euer dearly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: If it appeare not plaine, and proue vntrue,
Deadly diuorce ſtep betweene me and you.
O my deere mother do I ſee you liuing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine eyes ſmell Onions, I ſhall weepe anon: Good Tom Drumme lend me a handkercher. So I thanke thee, waite on me home, Ile make ſport with thee: Let thy curtsies alone, they are ſcuruy ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs from point to point this ſtorie know,
To make the euen truth in pleasure flow:
If thou beest yet a fresh vncropped flower,
Choose thou thy husband, and Ile pay thy dower.
For I can gueſſe, that by thy honeſt ayde,
Thou keptst a wife her ſelfe, thy ſelfe a Maide.
Of that and all the progreſſe more and leſſe,
Resoluedly more leasure ſhall expreſſe:
All yet ſeemes well, and if it end ſo meete,
The bitter past, more welcome is the ſweet.
The Kings a Begger, now the Play is done,
All is well ended, if this ſuite be wonne,
That you expreſſe Content: which we will pay,
With ſtrife to please you, day exceeding day:
Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts,
Your gentle hands lend vs, and take our hearts.
